html:
11.16.21  9:50 pm   where did the 2 week schedule go

      i'm wondering where it ever came from. i'm wondering this because it's impossible

11.16.21  9:23 pm   When you were writing your song "more than a dream", did you think to yourself, "I want to modulate down a minor third in the chorus",

     absolutely not

      or did this decision happen in a different, more natural way? (If so, an explanation of the way this decision happened would be appreciated)

      the best analogy i can think of is this: what made you decide to use the word "to" in your question? you probably did not make any conscious decision to use that word, but the word got used by you nonetheless. can we explain why? maybe not...... it's probably buried somewhere in the part of the brain that knows how to make things up

11.16.21  9:12 pm   What's the funniest thing

      waking up in the morning

11.16.21  8:30 pm   how do you answer all of these questions without going insane?

      went insane first. get that out of the way

11.16.21  8:28 pm   I have seen you answer the question "what was the bad thing" in reference to your song " Just Did A Bad Thing" and I'm confused how it's a bad thing. Why is spending the right amount of time on a song a bad thing?

      it's probably actually a good thing. but it always feels like the wrong thing, because of my strongly polarized goals

11.16.21  7:25 pm   How to open a bottle?

      there should be directions on it, or else it may be already open

11.16.21  7:24 pm   What are your thoughts on romanticism?

      sounds like that's gotta be just a longer word for romance

11.16.21  5:17 pm   A common criticism of my songs is that my mixes should be improved, but I have never really gotten any specific tips for a better mix. Do you have any tips for a generally good mix?

      you have to start with what you can hear. if you like your mixes the way they are, then there's no change that you can or should make. you have to do it based on what you hear. for example, if the trumpet is way way too loud...... if that bugs you when you listen to it, ... then you can turn it down. but if it doesn't bother you then there is no need to change it. If you already like it the way it is, and then you start changing it, you'll probably just end up making it worse. .... getting back to the original question, if someone else is claiming your 'mix' is 'bad', but not telling anything specific about what they don't like, then you can just maybe raise 1 eyebrow at them, if possible

11.16.21  5:15 pm   You said that music is "too good, but not good enough", but good enough for what?

      in some cases, certain music might not be good enough to cure every disease including death

11.16.21  8:09 am   every transcription I'm seeing of might quit has it in 12/8, same for most people I've heard talking about it, but it sounds like 4/4 with triplets??? Which one is it?

      12/8 is supposed to sound like 4/4 with triplets. 12/8 is basically a different way to write it down, if you don't want to have to write the number 3 all the time. take away all the 3's, but then to make up for it you have to add a dot next to every note that wasn't a triplet

11.15.21  9:06 am   Looking back at old questions, you seem pretty resolute in the idea that melody/lyrics come first, the melody has "chord residue" on it, and then you form the chords etc around that.

That makes a lot of sense to me, but I've found that since I'm not a lyricist (yet), that I tend to prefer to build a song from the emotions that I'm feeling, and those emotions come out most clearly in the form of a series of chords (with certain phrasings) on the piano. Melodies fall out later, sometimes out of those chord phrasings.

Do you think this difference in approach is just a matter of opinion?

     there's many different ways to do it. yours is good. if you ever get restless, you can switch, but you don't have to

     Could your stronger focus on lyrics be what creates that difference?

     i might be focusing on the lyrics slightly more than you might be, but i also focus on lyrics less than someone who writes lyrics first with no melody. i almost never do that. so in that sense i am somewhere in the middle. lyric/melody are linked for me, and that package is usually the driving force, but sometimes i do things differently. sometimes a vamp will be the first thing. sometimes a melody (no lyric) will be the first thing. occasionally lyric with no melody will be first, but that's only when i'm playing a ridiculous game i call "title first", and that's just for the title

     Or do you believe that I'd actually have a more fulfilling time with songwriting if I work on making lyrics and/or melodies first?

     if you start to get bored doing it the way you are doing it, then you could try other ways. but if you are enjoying your way then that means it's going good

11.15.21  4:18 am   how did you come up with the first key change in "more than a dream"? did you write the verse in F major and the chorus in D major separately and then write in ways to modulate between the two (like the weird harmony on "supposed to be") later,

     no

     or did you instinctively write the weird chords leaving the key after writing the parts in F and then go to D major without intending to,

     yes

      or was it something else?

(sorry if the question is worded in a confusing way)
